posts.title: I am not Anna
posts.markdown: Anna Santl is a twenty-year-old photographer based in Berlin. Her photo diary on tumblr is full of beautiful portraits and landscapes. I really enjoy the colours and the analog feel of her photos. Her work has been published on various blogs and in three exhibitions. ![](/content/images/2014/Aug/tumblr_n7xxf4OvoB1sp63m3o6_1280.jpg) ![](/content/images/2014/Aug/iamnotanna.jpg) ![](/content/images/2014/Aug/tumblr_nb2sw4TiKG1sp63m3o7_1280.jpg) ![](/content/images/2014/Aug/tumblr_nb2sw4TiKG1sp63m3o8_1280.jpg) ![](/content/images/2014/Aug/tumblr_n3re7m5Mmf1sp63m3o1_1280.jpg) View her tumblr
posts.html:
Anna Santl is a twenty-year-old photographer based in Berlin. Her photo diary on tumblr is full of beautiful portraits and landscapes. I really enjoy the colours and the analog feel of her photos. Her work has been published on various blogs and in three exhibitions.

View her tumblr

posts.title: Styleguide
posts.markdown:
Welcome to the styleguide for Pretty Stuff. It's going to be short and simple, but covers all that you need to know. ##Basics Pretty Stuff is all about imagery. The first priority is to make sure that your content and images fit the overall style of the site. Also, do not copy posts from other sites or post stuff that has been posted a million times before. Always try to be unique. ##Format Text and images are formatted via the Markdown syntax, making it easy to insert links and images. To read more about the syntax visit http://daringfireball.net/projects/markdown/syntax. Markdown also gives us the flexibility of using HTML wherever necessary. Links that refer to an external website automatically get a target="blank" property, so you don't have to add that manually. Paragraphs should not be too long. Always separate text like this, making it a nice reading experience for the user. ![](/content/images/2014/Aug/Bildschirmfoto-2014-08-31-um-13-49-56.png) You can easily create a grid of two images by wrapping them within a div with the class "split" like so:
![](/content/images/2014/Aug/koya-no-sumika-ma-style_9.jpg) ![](/content/images/2014/Aug/koya-no-sumika-ma-style_7.jpg)
Only use that on two images with the same height in a horizontal format. ![](/content/images/2014/Aug/Bildschirmfoto-2014-08-31-um-13-50-09.png) Thumbnails are automatically generated by taking the first image from the post. So always make sure this image is cropped to the size: __1200px by 800px.__ By using this size we are going to make sure that the posts on the homepage grid always have the same height, which is really important. The thumbnails are scaled down, so they don't get blurry on retina devices. Make sure to include a button at the end of every post linking to the website/project/person you are writing about, so they always get credit for their work. You can do that easily by using an HTML anchor tag with the class "button", like so: View this on Behance (or something similar) ##Social We are posting new content on social networks ourselves to make everything more personal. Always try to tag the site/person you are writing about via @company on Facebook and Twitter. Try to switch the header image on a regular basis so the profiles don't get boring.
posts.html:
Welcome to the styleguide for Pretty Stuff. It's going to be short and simple, but covers all that you need to know.

Basics

Pretty Stuff is all about imagery. The first priority is to make sure that your content and images fit the overall style of the site. Also, do not copy posts from other sites or post stuff that has been posted a million times before. Always try to be unique.

Format

Text and images are formatted via the Markdown syntax, making it easy to insert links and images. To read more about the syntax visit http://daringfireball.net/projects/markdown/syntax. Markdown also gives us the flexibility of using HTML wherever necessary.

Links that refer to an external website automatically get a target="blank" property, so you don't have to add that manually.

Paragraphs should not be too long. Always separate text like this, making it a nice reading experience for the user.

You can easily create a grid of two images by wrapping them within a div with the class "split" like so:

<div class="split">
![](/content/images/2014/Aug/koya-no-sumika-ma-style_9.jpg)
![](/content/images/2014/Aug/koya-no-sumika-ma-style_7.jpg)
</div>

Only use that on two images with the same height in a horizontal format.

Thumbnails are automatically generated by taking the first image from the post. So always make sure this image is cropped to the size: 1200px by 800px. By using this size we are going to make sure that the posts on the homepage grid always have the same height, which is really important. The thumbnails are scaled down, so they don't get blurry on retina devices.

Make sure to include a button at the end of every post linking to the website/project/person you are writing about, so they always get credit for their work. You can do that easily by using an HTML anchor tag with the class "button", like so:

<a href="yourlink" class="button">View this on Behance (or something similar)</a>

Social

We are posting new content on social networks ourselves to make everything more personal. Always try to tag the site/person you are writing about via @company on Facebook and Twitter.
Try to switch the header image on a regular basis so the profiles don't get boring.

posts.title: Suggest
posts.markdown: Did you find something you think is worth writing about? We'd love to see it! Just [send an email to us](mailto:hello@joshuasoehn.de?subject=Hey, I found something great) (this will launch your default e-mail client) or a mention to [@prettystuffio](http://twitter.com/prettystuffio). We'll inform you when we've posted your suggestion. Suggest via e-mail Thanks!
posts.html:

Just send an email to us (this will launch your default e-mail client) or a mention to @prettystuffio. We'll inform you when we've posted your suggestion.

posts.title: About
posts.markdown:
Pretty Stuff is an online magazine posting hand-selected work from the field of art, design, illustration and photography. We like to write about the good work we find when browsing the internet.
Joshua @joshuasoehn
Daniël @dvdwinden
We are always looking for people with a similar taste to ours, to help us out. If you think you are a good fit, please send a email to [hello@joshuasoehn.de](mailto:hello@joshuasoehn.de)
posts.html:
Pretty Stuff is an online magazine posting hand-selected work from the field of art, design, illustration and photography. We like to write about the good work we find when browsing the internet.

Joshua @joshuasoehn

Daniël @dvdwinden


We are always looking for people with a similar taste to ours, to help us out. If you think you are a good fit, please send a email to hello@joshuasoehn.de

posts.title: The Young Ones
posts.markdown: The Young Ones is a new magazine from Australia. It showcases the work of Melbourne based designers through images and interviews and focuses on unconventional paths to success. >Issue One profiles 14 creatives: A Friend of Mine, Alice Oehr, Amanda Cole, Beci Orpin, Bonnie Eichelberger, Dylan McDonough, Eliza Svikulis, Fawn Gallery, Full Drop Collective, Motherbird, Kristoffer Paulsen, Magdalena Ksiezak, Rob Cordiner, and Sean Morris. ![](/content/images/2014/Sep/10498086_350627771753396_2102902818186171462_o.jpg) ![](/content/images/2014/Sep/10615563_353163294833177_3425176963407877533_n.jpg) ![](/content/images/2014/Sep/tyo.jpg) ![](/content/images/2014/Sep/10560338_344871898995650_8193979167662831112_o.jpg) Purchase an issue
posts.html:
The Young Ones is a new magazine from Australia. It showcases the work of Melbourne based designers through images and interviews and focuses on unconventional paths to success.

Issue One profiles 14 creatives: A Friend of Mine, Alice Oehr, Amanda Cole, Beci Orpin, Bonnie Eichelberger, Dylan McDonough, Eliza Svikulis, Fawn Gallery, Full Drop Collective, Motherbird, Kristoffer Paulsen, Magdalena Ksiezak, Rob Cordiner, and Sean Morris.

Purchase an issue

posts.title: Daniel Gray
posts.markdown:
Daniel is a very talented book cover designer, who also writes for [Creative Review](http://creativereview.co.uk/), [Mac User](http://www.macuser.co.uk/) and [Brand Perfect](http://brandperfect.org/). What I like about his work is the consistency and simplicity, but also the fact that the covers are so to the point with the content. His site also contains a blog which is full of good posts and worth reading through.
![](/content/images/2014/Sep/Never-Let-Me-Go-1.jpg) ![](/content/images/2014/Sep/NEW_Afterthefact-1.jpg)
![](/content/images/2014/Sep/Daniel-Gray.jpg)

![](/content/images/2014/Sep/NewModernisms-1.jpg) ![](/content/images/2014/Sep/Vulture3-1.jpg)
Visit his portfolio

posts.title: Luis Mendo
posts.markdown: Luis Mendo is an 'editorial design consultant who draws and sometimes does commissioned illustration work'. The illustrations Luis does are what I like most. Luis has been designing since 1994 in The Netherlands, Japan and Spain, and opened his own design studio – [GOOD Inc.](http://www.goodinc.nl/) – in 2005. In 2009 he started drawing daily, which resulted in the beautiful illustrations you see below. His style is loose but every drawing perfectly sets a suitable tone. He recently wrote [a post about why you should draw every day](https://hi.co/moments/xm2teto1). Be sure to follow Luis on [Instagram](http://instagram.com/luismendo), too. ![](/content/images/2014/Sep/Luis_Mendo_icon001.jpg) ![](/content/images/2014/Sep/luismendo_petitnicholas_train-2.jpg) ![](/content/images/2014/Sep/Luis_Mendo_northface2.jpg) ![](/content/images/2014/Sep/Luis_mendo_NorthFace.jpg) Luismendo.com
posts.html:
Luis Mendo is an 'editorial design consultant who draws and sometimes does commissioned illustration work'. The illustrations Luis does are what I like most.

Luis has been designing since 1994 in The Netherlands, Japan and Spain, and opened his own design studio – GOOD Inc. – in 2005. In 2009 he started drawing daily, which resulted in the beautiful illustrations you see below. His style is loose but every drawing perfectly sets a suitable tone. He recently wrote a post about why you should draw every day.

Be sure to follow Luis on Instagram, too.

Luismendo.com

posts.title: Kimm Saatvedt
posts.markdown: Kimm Saatvedt is a Norwegian photographer based in Oslo. I had the pleasure of meeting him a couple of times when I lived there. He has an impressive portfolio with a wide variety of work, and has worked with some of the biggest companies in Norway. On his website you'll find work for Carl's Cars, Telenor, Subaru and Volkswagen, amongst others. His work is very well done and Kimm has a magnificent eye for detail. Follow Kimm on [Instagram](http://instagram.com/datafeil) and via [his blog](http://saatvedt.tumblr.com) for a peek into his life and work. ![](/content/images/2014/Sep/kimm02.jpg) ![](/content/images/2014/Sep/kimm01.jpg) ![](/content/images/2014/Sep/kimm03-1.jpg) ![](/content/images/2014/Sep/kimm04.jpg) kimm.no
posts.html:
Kimm Saatvedt is a Norwegian photographer based in Oslo. I had the pleasure of meeting him a couple of times when I lived there.
He has an impressive portfolio with a wide variety of work, and has worked with some of the biggest companies in Norway.

On his website you'll find work for Carl's Cars, Telenor, Subaru and Volkswagen, amongst others. His work is very well done and Kimm has a magnificent eye for detail.

Follow Kimm on Instagram and via his blog for a peek into his life and work.

kimm.no

posts.title: Lotta Nieminen
posts.markdown: I guess I'm telling you nothing new, when I say that Lotta is just awesome. She is an Illustrator, Graphic Designer and Art Director born in Helsinki, Finland, who is now running her own studio in New York. Before that she studied graphic design and illustration at the University of Art and Design Helsinki and the Rhode Island School of Design. She also worked for the fashion magazine Trendi, Pentagram Design and RoAndCo Studio. Her work always contains nice, pastel shade colors and her style is visible in every kind of work she has done. I highly suggest spending some time looking through her site, as this selection is just not enough to showcase her skills. ![](/content/images/2014/Sep/Lotta-Nieminen_Leader_13.jpg) ![](/content/images/2014/Sep/Lotta-Nieminen_Beautified_07B.jpg) ![](/content/images/2014/Sep/Lotta-Nieminen_Beautified_14.jpg) ![](/content/images/2014/Sep/Lotta-Nieminen_Matter_10.jpg) ![](/content/images/2014/Sep/Lotta-Nieminen_VanityFair_01.jpg) ![](/content/images/2014/Sep/Lotta-Nieminen_Walk_05.jpg) ![](/content/images/2014/Sep/Lotta-Nieminen_WalkStamp_02.jpg) ![](/content/images/2014/Sep/lottanieminen_GD_lula-01.jpg) lottanieminen.com
posts.html:
I guess I'm telling you nothing new, when I say that Lotta is just awesome. She is an Illustrator, Graphic Designer and Art Director born in Helsinki, Finland, who is now running her own studio in New York. Before that she studied graphic design and illustration at the University of Art and Design Helsinki and the Rhode Island School of Design.
She also worked for the fashion magazine Trendi, Pentagram Design and RoAndCo Studio.

Her work always contains nice, pastel shade colors and her style is visible in every kind of work she has done. I highly suggest spending some time looking through her site, as this selection is just not enough to showcase her skills.

lottanieminen.com

posts.title: Life & Thyme
posts.markdown: >A quarterly print publication documenting food culture around the globe with a storytelling sensibility. >For the past two years, Life & Thyme has been publishing stories on a weekly basis, covering food culture and the people behind it, exclusively on their website. These are stories about real people that work tirelessly in order to feed us. Life & Thyme is a beautiful website, about the poeple behind our food. They started a Kickstarter campaign to fund their next big project, bringing all the content into a print magazine. The photography and the snippets you see from the magazine look awesome and make sure you are not hungry before visiting their site. ![](/content/images/2014/Sep/1ba7d51dcdc1e79377936c7e8113ca22_large.jpg) ![](/content/images/2014/Sep/1ccc562844325ef8e5d98303baaceef2_large.jpg) ![](/content/images/2014/Sep/bb02ea29b6071d97d618c63c2e9cdbdd_large.jpg) ![](/content/images/2014/Sep/a90e457531e5d76b855f11132520fee9_large.jpg) _(Sorry for the low-quality images in this article)_ lifeandthyme.com
posts.html:
A quarterly print publication documenting food culture around the globe with a storytelling sensibility.

For the past two years, Life & Thyme has been publishing stories on a weekly basis, covering food culture and the people behind it, exclusively on their website. These are stories about real people that work tirelessly in order to feed us.

Life & Thyme is a beautiful website, about the poeple behind our food. They started a Kickstarter campaign to fund their next big project, bringing all the content into a print magazine.

The photography and the snippets you see from the magazine look awesome and make sure you are not hungry before visiting their site.

(Sorry for the low-quality images in this article)

lifeandthyme.com

posts.title: Present Plus
posts.markdown: Present Plus is a company situated in Amsterdam, The Netherlands. It was founded by [Nalden](http://nalden.net) and Damien Bradfield. [They've created great work](http://www.presentplus.com/answer?q=show%20me%20your%20work&o=0&l=100) for various companies – the website they did for [Powerhouse Company](http://powerhouse-company.com) is a good example – and they work on their own products, too. [Kuvva](http://kuvva.com), [WeTransfer](http://wetransfer.com) and the [One Minute Wonder series](http://oneminutewonder.tv) are all things they've (co-)founded. ![Present Plus's work](/content/images/2014/Oct/presentplus-work.png) ![Kuvva](/content/images/2014/Oct/kuvva.png) ![One Minute Wonder](/content/images/2014/Oct/oneminutewonder.png) Recently Present Plus relaunched their website with a bold move: they hid their navigation. ![The new Present Plus website](/content/images/2014/Nov/pp.jpg) Browsing to their website shows a search field in which you can start typing. If you type something like 'work' or 'show me your work', you'll be able to see what they do. Type 'where are you' and you'll find out their location. Of course, this move instigated a lot of discussion. They've explained why they did it [on their blog](http://www.presentplus.com/article/its-a-hunch). > “We have attempted to build a small search engine, a custom CMS to input questions and answers and a brutal approach to the things we have created over the last 4 years to only show the stuff thats relevant. > We’ve killed off the standard menu bar, incorporated voice recognition and built a site driven by experience and not by page rankings.” I think the decision to hide their navigation is fine. Maybe not for users who aren't that tech-savvy, but I don't think Present Plus is aiming at those users (and then again; people are more tech-savvy than ever). Present Plus is an innovative company which does things their own way. A company that takes initiative and creates things they want to create themselves. That being said, this piece of navigation – which requires users to browse actively instead of passively – really suits them as a company. People who like it and send them an email will probably be the people they want to work with. Folks who don't get it or want to use it are probably the ones they're hoping to filter out. Present Plus
posts.html:
Present Plus is a company situated in Amsterdam, The Netherlands. It was founded by Nalden and Damien Bradfield. They've created great work for various companies – the website they did for Powerhouse Company is a good example – and they work on their own products, too. Kuvva, WeTransfer and the One Minute Wonder series are all things they've (co-)founded.

Recently Present Plus relaunched their website with a bold move: they hid their navigation.

Browsing to their website shows a search field in which you can start typing. If you type something like 'work' or 'show me your work', you'll be able to see what they do. Type 'where are you' and you'll find out their location.

Of course, this move instigated a lot of discussion. They've explained why they did it on their blog.

“We have attempted to build a small search engine, a custom CMS to input questions and answers and a brutal approach to the things we have created over the last 4 years to only show the stuff thats relevant.

We’ve killed off the standard menu bar, incorporated voice recognition and built a site driven by experience and not by page rankings.”

I think the decision to hide their navigation is fine. Maybe not for users who aren't that tech-savvy, but I don't think Present Plus is aiming at those users (and then again; people are more tech-savvy than ever).

Present Plus is an innovative company which does things their own way. A company that takes initiative and creates things they want to create themselves. That being said, this piece of navigation – which requires users to browse actively instead of passively – really suits them as a company.

People who like it and send them an email will probably be the people they want to work with. Folks who don't get it or want to use it are probably the ones they're hoping to filter out.

Present Plus

posts.title: Hopscotch
posts.markdown: Hopscotch from London are loving good design and that’s what they are all about — finding beautiful looking things to adorn you and your home. Hopscotch is a hand picked selection of homewares, accessories, jewellery, beauty products, prints and vintage goods from around the world. They are focused on style, craftsmanship and quality. >Our favourite products are clean in design, fresh and fun and have all been curated from our East London studio. We sell an eclectic mix of signature designed products, items from our favourite UK and International designers, artists and makers, along with vintage items sourced throughout Europe. ![](/content/images/2014/Nov/hopscotch_1.jpg) ![](/content/images/2014/Nov/hopscotch_thumb-1.jpg) ![](/content/images/2014/Nov/hopscotch_2.jpg) ![](/content/images/2014/Nov/hopscotch_4.jpg) ![](/content/images/2014/Nov/hopscotch_5.jpg) ![](/content/images/2014/Nov/hopscotch_3.jpg) Visit their shop
posts.html:
Hopscotch from London are loving good design and that’s what they are all about — finding beautiful looking things to adorn you and your home.

Hopscotch is a hand picked selection of homewares, accessories, jewellery, beauty products, prints and vintage goods from around the world. They are focused on style, craftsmanship and quality.

Our favourite products are clean in design, fresh and fun and have all been curated from our East London studio. We sell an eclectic mix of signature designed products, items from our favourite UK and International designers, artists and makers, along with vintage items sourced throughout Europe.

Visit their shop

posts.title: A Man Of Few Words
posts.markdown: AMOFW are Jarek and Angela from Poland. The concept behind A Man Of Few Words is to create items that are they're interpretation of classics, therefore to create new looks that stay classy. They use only natural and hight quality materials. All items are made locally – in Poland, by small manufacturers. >Since ages we value quality more than quantity when making purchases anything. So, when it turned out that the biggest problem for us was to get good quality, classic and simple items from shirt to clutch, so we decided that we will start doing it ourselves. And you know what? We loved it. It’s a big pleasure for us to look for the finest materials in small factories in Poland, so then with the group of our craftmans neatly cutting out the fabrics and finally sewing everything. We really like watch over all stages of creation, focusing on craftmanship and local producion which are deeply-rooted in our every product. We do our best to produce items that will live with you and make you happy for years. >A man of few words is a person who speaks concisely. Few words but with a lot of sense. That is exactly our attitude. We expand this idiom as this is not only a matter of speaking but whole way of life. >We get inspiration mainly from traveling which is our addiction now. Our first collection „Como Unspoken” is inspired by Lake Como in Italy. Inspirations also come from architecture, photography and cinema. ![](/content/images/2014/Nov/amofw-simple-design.jpg) ![](/content/images/2014/Nov/amofw-como-LB-9.jpg) ![](/content/images/2014/Nov/amofw.jpg) ![](/content/images/2014/Nov/amofw-como-LB-4.jpg) ![](/content/images/2014/Nov/amofw-8103.jpg) ![](/content/images/2014/Nov/amofw-front-3.jpg) ![](/content/images/2014/Nov/amofw-como-LB-7.jpg) Visit shop
posts.html:
AMOFW are Jarek and Angela from Poland.

The concept behind A Man Of Few Words is to create items that are they're interpretation of classics, therefore to create new looks that stay classy. They use only natural and hight quality materials. All items are made locally – in Poland, by small manufacturers.

Since ages we value quality more than quantity when making purchases anything. So, when it turned out that the biggest problem for us was to get good quality, classic and simple items from shirt to clutch, so we decided that we will start doing it ourselves. And you know what? We loved it. It’s a big pleasure for us to look for the finest materials in small factories in Poland, so then with the group of our craftmans neatly cutting out the fabrics and finally sewing everything. We really like watch over all stages of creation, focusing on craftmanship and local producion which are deeply-rooted in our every product. We do our best to produce items that will live with you and make you happy for years.

A man of few words is a person who speaks concisely. Few words but with a lot of sense. That is exactly our attitude. We expand this idiom as this is not only a matter of speaking but whole way of life.

We get inspiration mainly from traveling which is our addiction now. Our first collection „Como Unspoken” is inspired by Lake Como in Italy. Inspirations also come from architecture, photography and cinema.

Visit shop

posts.title: Hem
posts.markdown:
Hem is a swedish furniture brand, and it's passion is to make it easy for everyone to enjoy design. They offer original design products as well as many customisation options thanks to our online tools. They team up with the most exciting designers of today to create a new generation of original furniture and interior accessories. Hem is a very global company based in Berlin, but the designers are from Stockholm, the product development team is based in Helsinki and the production team is from Warsaw. They also ship to a lot of countries. ![](/content/images/2014/Dec/hem.jpg) ![](/content/images/2014/Dec/hem_2.jpg) ![](/content/images/2014/Dec/01_11_Technology.jpg) ![](/content/images/2014/Dec/01_07_Design.jpg) A personal highlight of mine is their insanely good [Instagram account](http://instagram.com/hemishere) and they teamed up with some famous instagramers to get those photos.
![](/content/images/2014/Dec/10784856_570499623084053_323138093_n.jpg) ![](/content/images/2014/Dec/10785038_1500519336876213_266787881_n.jpg)
![](/content/images/2014/Dec/10808632_342854302568756_4252214_n.jpg) ![](/content/images/2014/Dec/10809600_1525573481018361_1610250568_n.jpg)
![](/content/images/2014/Dec/01_05_Featured-Hai_mobile.jpg) Visit the shop
posts.html:
Hem is a swedish furniture brand, and it's passion is to make it easy for everyone to enjoy design. They offer original design products as well as many customisation options thanks to our online tools. They team up with the most exciting designers of today to create a new generation of original furniture and interior accessories.

Hem is a very global company based in Berlin, but the designers are from Stockholm, the product development team is based in Helsinki and the production team is from Warsaw. They also ship to a lot of countries.

A personal highlight of mine is their insanely good Instagram account and they teamed up with some famous instagramers to get those photos.

Visit the shop

posts.title: Kali
posts.markdown: Beautiful and minimalistic captures from Hamburg-based and self taught photographer [Matthias Heiderich](http://www.matthias-heiderich.de/). posts.title: Reshaping the fundamental
posts.markdown:
When I started building my own websites there was always the time where I had to redesign them. Over and over again. I guess that’s the problem most people have when it comes to building stuff form themselves, it’s never finished. I decided to update this blog to a newer version of the [Ghost CMS](https://ghost.org/) and that’s how it started.

First I just thought it would be nice to have fullscreen cover photos with text on it and nicer pages for the authors, but from looking at that site for some hours something was bugging me, the sidebar was unusual and taking away from the content, actual photos in the article were to small. I decided to stick with my gut and to change some stuff around, trying to stick to my original style of designing: keeping things minimal.

236 additions and 193 deletions later, that’s what I did: New font for headlines (which I may change), white background, finally a footer and just a big grid of post. The header itself is super small, all focus should be on the content. We have some nice new [author profiles](http://prettystuff.io/author/joshua-soehn/) (we are still looking for awesome new folks) and a slightly new about page. I know that the words-per-line amount in the paragraphs is slightly to much, but bumping up the font-size looks weird and I want the images to actual be wider. 

If you want to play around with the site, it is now open source on [Github](https://github.com/joshuasoehn/prettystuff), there is even a little introduction on how to run it locally. Feel free to mess around with it, but please don’t steal, the code isn’t good enough anyway. If you find a bug and you are on Github, please open an issue there.

This post and the next one should start creating a theme of how I want post on Pretty Stuff to look and feel like, but it’s hard to find such content so please be patient with us.

If you have any feedback, problems or advises, please send them [this way](mailto:hello@joshuasoehn.de). Thank you for your support!

The hero-image from this post is from [Kinfolk’s In Praise Of Slowness](http://www.kinfolk.com/in-praise-of-slowness/). All credit goes to them.
posts.html:
When I started building my own websites there was always the time where I had to redesign them. Over and over again. I guess that’s the problem most people have when it comes to building stuff form themselves, it’s never finished. I decided to update this blog to a newer version of the Ghost CMS and that’s how it started.

First I just thought it would be nice to have fullscreen cover photos with text on it and nicer pages for the authors, but from looking at that site for some hours something was bugging me, the sidebar was unusual and taking away from the content, actual photos in the article were to small. I decided to stick with my gut and to change some stuff around, trying to stick to my original style of designing: keeping things minimal.

236 additions and 193 deletions later, that’s what I did: New font for headlines (which I may change), white background, finally a footer and just a big grid of post. The header itself is super small, all focus should be on the content. We have some nice new author profiles (we are still looking for awesome new folks) and a slightly new about page. I know that the words-per-line amount in the paragraphs is slightly to much, but bumping up the font-size looks weird and I want the images to actual be wider.

If you want to play around with the site, it is now open source on Github, there is even a little introduction on how to run it locally. Feel free to mess around with it, but please don’t steal, the code isn’t good enough anyway. If you find a bug and you are on Github, please open an issue there.

This post and the next one should start creating a theme of how I want post on Pretty Stuff to look and feel like, but it’s hard to find such content so please be patient with us.

If you have any feedback, problems or advises, please send them this way. Thank you for your support!

The hero-image from this post is from Kinfolk’s In Praise Of Slowness. All credit goes to them.

posts.title: A Merry Mishap
posts.markdown:
A Merry Mishap is the blog of Jennifer, a photographer and blogger from the US, where she lives with her husband and 2 kids. I discovered her through [Instagram](http://instagram.com/amerrymishap/) where she already is one of the famous with over 80k followers. Her blog inspires me a lot and I really like the Nordic and Scandinavian influences you see all over her home. She might not need the little extra traffic coming from this site, but for those of you who don’t know her, it would be a shame to not introduce her blog. (Sorry for the tons of vertical photos in this post) ![](/content/images/2015/02/16568081025_66ca83491d_o.jpg) ![](/content/images/2015/02/14890197575_77b6d4fc49_o.jpg) ![](/content/images/2015/02/16260900200_329afe3dcb_o.jpg)
![](/content/images/2015/02/16495753825_0f7c84c074_o-1.jpg) ![](/content/images/2015/02/15884643963_3a00193b87_o.jpg)
![](/content/images/2015/02/S1.jpg) ![](/content/images/2015/02/16432107951_6bfffcf6df_o.jpg) View her blog
posts.html:
A Merry Mishap is the blog of Jennifer, a photographer and blogger from the US, where she lives with her husband and 2 kids. I discovered her through Instagram where she already is one of the famous with over 80k followers. Her blog inspires me a lot and I really like the Nordic and Scandinavian influences you see all over her home. She might not need the little extra traffic coming from this site, but for those of you who don’t know her, it would be a shame to not introduce her blog.

(Sorry for the tons of vertical photos in this post)

posts.title: Kasper Laigaard
posts.markdown: Kasper Laigaard previously worked at the brilliant Danish digital agency [Hello Monday](http://hellomonday.com) as an Art Director/Designer and went freelance a while ago. To do so, he designed himself a new responsive portfolio website. I am very fond of digital design coming from Scandinavia and Kasper’s website is no exception. Type is set in [Patron](http://www.milieugrotesque.com/typefaces/patron/) by Milieu Grotesque and [Apercu Mono](http://www.colophon-foundry.org/fonts/apercu) by the Colophon Type Foundry, which work really well together. ![The type game is strong in this one](/content/images/2015/03/kasper-laigaard-case.png) The case pages are wonderful; the big images allow you to really take in the work and the photography is very well done. Presenting cases on devices doesn’t always work that well, but Kasper has nailed it here. ![Kasper's work for ISSUU](/content/images/2015/03/kasper-laigaard-issuu.png) ![Bang & Olufsen app](/content/images/2015/03/kasper-laigaard-bang-olufsen.png) On his portfolio you'll find the work he did for ISSUU, Bang & Olufsen and RVLT. All these projects were done at Hello Monday. A first taste of his personal work can be seen in his – soon to be updated – case for Mumilab, the studio of Peter Ravnsborg, a Danish photographer. ![Hello Monday's grid-based design](/content/images/2015/03/kasper-laigaard-hello-monday-1.png) ![Mumilab logotype](/content/images/2015/03/kasper-laigaard-mumilab.png) To me, there’s one downside to Kasper’s portfolio. After grabbing my attention with all the great finished work, I want to know more about the process. How did the projects end up the way they did and what were the challenges he/they faced along the way? I’d love some words to accompany the images. I am excited to see what we’ll see next from Kasper. Kasper Laigaard
posts.html:
Kasper Laigaard previously worked at the brilliant Danish digital agency Hello Monday as an Art Director/Designer and went freelance a while ago.

To do so, he designed himself a new responsive portfolio website. I am very fond of digital design coming from Scandinavia and Kasper’s website is no exception. Type is set in Patron by Milieu Grotesque and Apercu Mono by the Colophon Type Foundry, which work really well together.

The case pages are wonderful; the big images allow you to really take in the work and the photography is very well done. Presenting cases on devices doesn’t always work that well, but Kasper has nailed it here.

On his portfolio you'll find the work he did for ISSUU, Bang & Olufsen and RVLT. All these projects were done at Hello Monday. A first taste of his personal work can be seen in his – soon to be updated – case for Mumilab, the studio of Peter Ravnsborg, a Danish photographer.

To me, there’s one downside to Kasper’s portfolio. After grabbing my attention with all the great finished work, I want to know more about the process. How did the projects end up the way they did and what were the challenges he/they faced along the way? I’d love some words to accompany the images.

I am excited to see what we’ll see next from Kasper.

Kasper Laigaard
posts.meta_description: Kasper Laigaard previously worked at the brilliant Danish digital agency Hello Monday as an Art Director and went freelance a while ago.

posts.title: Aether Cone
posts.markdown: Cone is the first music player that thinks. It listens to your requests, picks up on your habits, and learns your tastes to create the perfect soundtrack for any mood or moment. >Our world has changed a lot since the days of records and CD’s. Endless choice hasn’t always made life better. Often, it means we settle for silence. >We believe it’s time to put music back into our daily lives, simply and beautifully. We envision evenings with friends where no one has to mind the music. >Cone learns what you like, and plays what you love. ![](/content/images/2015/03/aether_cone_photography_3.jpg) ![](/content/images/2015/03/aether_cone_photography_6-1.jpg) ![](/content/images/2015/03/aether_cone_photography_1b.jpg) ![](/content/images/2015/03/aether_cone_photography_8.jpg) ![](/content/images/2015/03/aether_cone_photography_2.jpg) Learn more about Cone
posts.html:
Cone is the first music player that thinks. It listens to your requests, picks up on your habits, and learns your tastes to create the perfect soundtrack for any mood or moment.

Our world has changed a lot since the days of records and CD’s. Endless choice hasn’t always made life better. Often, it means we settle for silence.

We believe it’s time to put music back into our daily lives, simply and beautifully. We envision evenings with friends where no one has to mind the music.

Cone learns what you like, and plays what you love.

Learn more about Cone

posts.title: Buttur Is Better
posts.markdown: Buttur is a husband and wife team trained as an Industrial Designer and Color Specialist. After several years of working in the product design industry with a focus on technology, they started Buttur to gain an analog and wholesome experience to designing and manufacturing products. Together they design and manufacture handsome products for the enlightened by transforming their experiences with everyday moments into tangible objects. They source manufacturing in the USA, while working very closely with suppliers to achieve the highest quality results. ![](/content/images/2015/04/20150117-L1000190-01-.jpg) ![](/content/images/2015/04/20150117-L1000168--01-.jpg) ![](/content/images/2015/04/20150118-L1000016-2-01-.jpg) ![](/content/images/2015/04/package-topview.jpg) ![](/content/images/2015/04/making08.jpg) ![](/content/images/2015/04/Woodie07e.jpg) ![](/content/images/2015/04/holding-book.jpg) ![](/content/images/2015/04/20150117-L1000144.jpg) ![](/content/images/2015/04/20150118-L1000165.jpg) Butter Is Better Shop
posts.html:
Buttur is a husband and wife team trained as an Industrial Designer and Color Specialist. After several years of working in the product design industry with a focus on technology, they started Buttur to gain an analog and wholesome experience to designing and manufacturing products. Together they design and manufacture handsome products for the enlightened by transforming their experiences with everyday moments into tangible objects. They source manufacturing in the USA, while working very closely with suppliers to achieve the highest quality results.

Butter Is Better Shop
